nodes.text: Input-aware selective instruction duplication (SID) that adapts protection to runtime inputs can substantially reduce silent data corruption (SDC) coverage loss compared to existing input-agnostic SID techniques while remaining lightweight and practical for HPC deployment
Existing SID methods derive vulnerability profiles from a single default reference input and assume input-invariant SDC propagation, causing underprotection or overprotection when inputs vary

Empirical evaluation across 30 inputs for 10 HPC applications shows large ranges of SDC coverage when using reference-input-based SID (coverage often falls well below reference), demonstrating substantial coverage loss across inputs

Protego: a two-phase input-aware SID framework consisting of a one-time offline vulnerability-guided input exploration and grouping, plus a lightweight runtime classifier that selects a precomputed representative SID-protected executable based on input-argument features

One-time SDC vulnerability-guided search: generate and evaluate 500 informative inputs via mutation and crossover, prioritize inputs that maximize diversity in instruction-level SDC vulnerability profiles using fault injection (FI)

Input grouping analysis: cluster the explored inputs into a small number of input groups by minimizing maximum allowable SDC coverage loss within groups (selecting a 10% threshold) and pick a representative input and its SID-protected executable per group

Feature selection and model training: derive candidate transformations of input arguments, select top 5 features using mutual information, and train an MLP (five hidden layers 512-256-128-64-32, ReLU, Adam) on the 500-input dataset to predict overall SDC vulnerability from input features

Runtime deployment: extract the preselected top-5 argument-derived features from an unseen input, use the trained MLP to estimate overall SDC vulnerability, map the estimate to the nearest input group, and return the group's precomputed representative SID-protected executable without runtime FI or dynamic profiling

Protego reduces mean SDC coverage loss across diverse inputs compared to baseline SID: evaluation on 10 HPC applications shows substantially lower average coverage loss (evaluation reports reductions in mean loss across protection budgets; e.g., per-paper summary: average loss reduced from around 21% to 10% across inputs)

Per-application example: LU application mean SDC coverage loss at 10%, 30%, 50%, 70% overheads drops from baseline values 13.33%, 11.29%, 7.09%, 4.94% to Protego values 4.88%, 4.35%, 3.73%, 1.84%; overall across 10 apps baseline averages 23.81%, 18.76%, 16.36%, 13.14% vs Protego 15.18%, 12.71%, 11.62%, 8.43%

Protego achieves low runtime overhead: selecting a representative protected executable at runtime takes about 0.05 seconds on average vs about 5 seconds for full duplication deployment, yielding roughly 100x speedup compared to full duplication

Case study on high SDC-prone inputs: Protego substantially outperforms static SID under high-risk inputs (average coverage loss across apps for baseline 22.89% vs Protego 6.41%), showing particular effectiveness when inputs activate regions unseen by reference input

Offline cost and limitation: the one-time vulnerability-guided search and FI are expensive (reported average offline search time ~3500 minutes and SID evaluation ~880 minutes across applications), although this cost is incurred only once per application

Conclusion: Precomputing a small set of representative SID-protected executables via guided FI and using lightweight input-argument features plus an MLP to choose among them at runtime provides a practical trade-off that mitigates input-induced SDC coverage loss while avoiding expensive runtime FI or dynamic profiling
